title: Python versions
text:
The PyAnsys ecosystem follows SPEC-0 for Python version support,
which is also similar to NEP 29. This means:
PyAnsys packages are expected to drop support for Python versions 3 years after their
initial release.
You can find below the timeline for the end of support for each Python version according to the SPEC-0 policy
as well as a table showing the Python versions supported by each PyAnsys metapackage, which might slightly
differ from the SPEC-0 policy but is always aligned with it.
Grayed out Python versions are no longer supported by the current version of the PyAnsys metapackage.
Light blue Python versions are currently supported.
Dark blue Python versions are upcoming Python releases for which support is expected in the future.
Some extra remarks:
The length of the Python version boxes is indicative of the support duration according to the SPEC-0 policy.
The color of the Python version boxes is indicative of the PyAnsys metapackage current support.
Below you can find a list of the Python versions supported by each PyAnsys metapackage release:
Package version
Python versions supported
2023.1
Python 3.7 - Python 3.10
2023.2
Python 3.8 - Python 3.11
2024.1
Python 3.9 - Python 3.12
2024.2
Python 3.9 - Python 3.12
development
Python 3.10 - Python 3.12
Python versions

title: Getting started
text:
PyAnsys libraries fall into two categories:
Wrappers over products like MAPDL, Fluent, or AEDT
Supporting libraries like DPF
Most PyAnsys packages require a local installation of Ansys. The version
of Ansys installed dictates the interface and features available to
you. However, PyAnsys libraries use gRPC to communicate to the
products, you can have the product installed remotely and connect to that
remote instance. This still requires that you need a copy of Ansys installed on
the host machine.
For more information on getting a licensed copy of Ansys, visit Ansys. If you are a student, consider installing a student version by
visiting Ansys for Students.
Getting started

title: Getting started > Installation
text:
There are several ways of installing PyAnsys depending on your use case, but
the easiest is simply to run:
This installs all the PyAnsys libraries for the latest released
version of Ansys, for example, v2023R1.
You can always install libraries individually by visiting the install page for
each library. For example, for PyAEDT:
Installation

title: Getting started > User mode installation
text:
Before installing pyansys in user mode, ensure that you have the latest
version of pip with:
Then, install pyansys with:
If you are interested in installing an extra target such as fluent-all:
If you are interested in installing a specific version such as 2023.1.0:
User mode installation
pyansys
pyansys
fluent-all
2023.1.0

title: Getting started > Offline mode installation
text:
If you lack an internet connection on your installation machine, the
recommended way of installing the pyansys metapackage is downloading the
wheelhouse archive from the Releases Page for your
corresponding machine architecture.
Each wheelhouse archive contains all the Python wheels necessary to install
pyansys metapackage from scratch on Windows, Linux, and MacOS from Python
3.10 to 3.12. You can install this on an isolated system with a fresh Python
installation or on a virtual environment.
For example, on Linux with Python 3.10, unzip the wheelhouse archive and install
it with the following:
If you’re on Windows with Python 3.10, unzip to a wheelhouse directory and install using the same command as above.
Consider installing using a virtual environment.
Offline mode installation
pyansys
pyansys

title: Getting started > Versioning system
text:
The pyansys metapackage follows a semantic-like versioning system, though
it has been adapted to the Ansys product release mechanism. In that sense, the
following kind of versioning system is followed:
Where:
XXXX is the Ansys product release year (for example, 2022)
Y is the Ansys product release within the same year (for example, 1,
which relates to R1)
ZZ is the patched versions to the pyansys metapackage, if any.
Consequently, the first pyansys metapackage compatible with the 2024 R2
release would be:
And any subsequent patched version of that package would be:
You can request for a specific version install when pip installing your package:
Versioning system
pyansys
XXXX
Y
ZZ
pyansys
pyansys

title: User guide
text:
User guides for the different pyansys packages can be found in their specific documentation.
The pyansys metapackage itself has no functionalities on its own. It is only a bundle of the
different public PyAnsys libraries that are compatible with a given Ansys Unified Install depending
on the version requested.
User guide
pyansys
pyansys

title: Examples > PyAnsys packages examples
text:
Combining PyAnsys libraries?
If you are using multiple PyAnsys libraries, you can find examples on how to combine them
in the PyAnsys Workflows page. This page contains
practical examples on how to chain different PyAnsys libraries together.
PyAnsys packages examples

title: Other tools
text:
Standalone projects, tooling libraries and toolkits related to the PyAnsys ecosystem.
Standalone projects to exploit the full potential of the PyAnsys ecosystem
Additional libraries delivered with the tools target of the PyAnsys metapackage
Toolkits built on top of PyAnsys libraries for specific purposes.
Other tools
tools

title: Tooling libraries
text:
Simple gRPC API tool for moving files between a client and a remote server
Python utility for launching Ansys products on a local machine and configuring their launch settings
Library to locate Ansys products in a local machine
Utility library to compile .proto files to Python source when building the package wheel
Python interface between PyAnsys libraries and plotting backends
Tool for reporting your Python environment’s package versions and hardware resources in a standardized way
Tool for defining basic variables, types, metadata, and values intended to provide interoperability between all products
Tool for backwards and forwards server support
Pythonic interface for units, unit systems, and unit conversions
Python package for unifying material management across the Ansys portfolio
Tooling libraries
.proto

title: API reference
text:
The pyansys metapackage on its own does not have a specific API. The only information specific-only
to this package that can be provided is its version. This can be looked up as follows:
However, each of the PyAnsys packages that shape the pyansys metapackage have their own specific API
reference section. In order to navigate through them, please refer to their documentation.
API reference
pyansys
pyansys

title: API reference > PyAnsys packages API reference
text: PyAnsys packages API reference

title: PyAnsys
text:
Welcome to the PyAnsys project. While this project originated as a single pyansys package,
it is now a collection of many Python packages for using Ansys products through Python:
Pythonic interface to Ansys Composite PrepPost (ACP)
Pythonic interface to the Ansys Additive service
PyAdditive widget toolkit to visualize additive parametric study results
Pythonic interface to Ansys Electronics Desktop (AEDT)
Pythonic interface to the Ansys Geometry service
Pythonic interface to PyAnsys Math libraries
Pythonic interface to Ansys Sound
Pythonic interface to Ansys ConceptEV library
Pythonic interface to the Data Processing Framework (DPF) for building advanced and customized workflows
Pythonic interface to access and postprocess Ansys solver result files
Pythonic interface to postprocess layered and short-fiber composite models
Pythonic interface to build the Ansys DYNA input deck, submit it to the Ansys LS-DYNA solver, and postprocess its results
Pythonic interface to Ansys Dynamic Reporting for service and control of its database and reports
Pythonic interface to the Ansys Electronics Database (EDB) client library
Pythonic interface to Ansys Electronics Database (EDB)
Pythonic interface to EnSight, the Ansys simulation postprocessor
Pythonic interface to Ansys Fluent
Pythonic interface to visualize Ansys Fluent simulations
Pythonic interface to Ansys Granta MI services
Pythonic interface to Ansys HPC Platform Services (HPS)
Pythonic interface to Ansys MAPDL (Mechanical APDL)
Pythonic interface to read legacy MAPDL result files (MAPDL 14.5 and later)
Pythonic interface to Ansys Mechanical
Pythonic interface to Ansys ModelCenter
Pythonic interface to Ansys Motor-CAD
Pythonic interface to Ansys optiSLang
Pythonic interface to the Ansys PIM (Product Instance Management) API
Python library to acquire geometries and prepare surface and volume meshes for multiple solvers
Python interface to Ansys Rocky using Rocky PrePost API
Pythonic interface to Ansys RedHawkSC and TotemSC
Pythonic interface to Ansys Sherlock
Pythonic interface to SimAI
Pythonic interface to Ansys System Coupling
Pythonic interface to Ansys TurboGrid, a high-quality turbomachinery meshing software app
Pythonic interface to communicate with consumption workflows for Ansys digital twins
Pythonic interface to Ansys Workbench
Shared Ansys software components to enable package interoperability and minimize maintenance
PyAnsys
pyansys
